episodes.title: Bob Minton: Scientology wants your money and your life 3/3
episodes.description:
Moderator: Any visitor to the former pirate haven of Clearwater on Florida's west coast quickly realizes who is fighting for power today. Scientologists have taken over the street scene, predominantly in the downtown area. In Clearwater they are a great deal closer to their dream of having their own Scientology city. Of the 100,000 inhabitants today, 6,000 are said to belong to the sect. On top of that, Scientology tourists come here from all over the world. 

They make the pilgrimage to this former luxury hotel and pay thousands of dollars for courses which promise them a higher level of enlightenment. Fort Harrison is their religious center. Whoever approaches it is under observation. The sect's security service accompanies our team step by step. Scientology sheriffs report every enemy movement by radio to their center.

episodes.title: Bob Minton: Scientology wants your money and your life 1/3
episodes.description:
Journalist: Why do you accuse all critics of wanting to destroy your church? 

Anderson: That would be silly. I don't have any problem with critics, whether they're on the internet or otherwise. Who's worried about critics? 

Journalist: You. You hate critics. 

Anderson: What bothers me are individuals who only want one thing: to destroy religious minorities. I saw both of these people outside in front of Fort Harrison. That was your big demonstration? All that does is make me laugh, and ask myself, "Don't they have anything better to do?" Is that their only goal, to suck like leeches on the nerves of a church?

episodes.title: The Religious Intolerance of Scientology 3/3
episodes.description:
Stacy Young: "...what they give you is a program so that you can set up your website  but you take that disc and put that into your computer, unbeknownst to you, also includes an censoring program...you can't get on  other websites to see the truth of what's going on with the current organization. So they control your information..."

"I think it's important to say that the majority of the people that are in Scientology have no idea that any of this intimidation and harassment of critics and former Scientologists is going on at all..."

"I was actually sent to a Scientology prison camp, which is called a Rehabilitation Project Force, and it's something somewhere to a political reeducation camp where someone is a dissident and is held against their will until they are broken and agree to toe the party line again."

episodes.title: The Religious Intolerance of Scientology 2/3
episodes.description:
Barnes: "They cry religious intolerance,  for being persecuted, for being discriminated against, but they are the biggest violators of that, of any organizations I've ever seen."

"If you are a Scientologist and you don't agree with what the current management is doing, or certain official, they will put extreme pressures upon you to make you change your mind. And if you don't, what will ensue from there will be character assassination, spreading lies about you cause they're gonna kill the messenger, not the message."

"The church of Scientology is never wrong. I've never seen this organization apologize for any activities  it's ever done. Ever. They've never even apologized to Lisa Mcpherson; they still think they were practicing their religion. They WEREN'T practicing their religion. They were lying to the press and they've lied to the public about Lisa Mcpherson."

episodes.title: The Religious Intolerance of Scientology 1/3
episodes.description:
Ex-Scientologists Stacy Young and Greg Barnes to Syl Farrell about the lies Scientology manufactures and the smear campaign Scientology wages against Germany. 

Barnes: "If what had happened to me had happened to you, and you tell me about it, I wouldn't believe you. Because it's too unbelievable that here's an organization that puts out all these front groups, like we wanna stop mental health abuse, literacy programs etc. There's nothing wrong with these. You know our basic fundamental believes of Scientology is freedom of speech and religious freedom and freedom of association...there's nothing wrong with these things. But these things are only fronts, because they are not applied. And if you become a free thinker in the current organization, you are quickly squished."

episodes.title: Scientology: CAN is the Nazi and the KKK (CBS 60 minutes)2/2
episodes.description:
LESLEY STAHL: There was a time, if you were worried about your son or daughter being in a cult, you could get help from a small, nonprofit organization called the Cult Awareness Network, or CAN, for twenty years the nation's best-known resource for information and advice about groups it considered dangerous. Among them was Scientology, a church not known for turning the other cheek. 

Stacy Young: Someone who speaks publically against Scientology is targeted for a campaign of harassment, character assassination, financial ruin...there's a policy that says specifically, "If possible, ruin them utterly." 

The classic story of how Scientology destroys enemy of the church now in higher quality. Scientology again compares critics of the church to Nazi and KKK, whereas Scientology itself to Jews and African Americans.

episodes.title: YouTube is Suppressing Contents that Expose Scientology
episodes.description:
http://dotsub.com/films/youtubeis/
http://crypticclarity.com/evidence-lots-of-screenshots-that-google-is-suppressing-contents-exposing-scientology/
(follow the above links to see the video)
When I tried to watch the 60 minutes coverage of CAN, the video wouldn't play. I then went to the front page to try the other non-Scientology related videos, which all played just fine. I went back to try more videos on my channel, none of them would play (with the strange exception of the 2nd segment from "The S Files", which YouTube actually held hostage for some 29 hours after my upload before releasing it online). I tried more non-Scientology videos. All played smoothly. How about the "Scientology song"? It wouldn't play. At the end I clicked on the Stacy Young interview on my play list. It wouldn't play.

episodes.title: Greater Boston: Bob Minton Interview 4
episodes.description:
Cult expert Steven Hassen:
"I've seen a systematic tactics to harass critics including myself, legal harassment, hiring private investigators, going through my garbage, going to my neighbors, spreading lies about me...basically I thinkreligion is a very important thing; I believe in God, I believe in human right and any legitimate religion should be upfront and tell people what they believe, who they are and what is expected of them. In this particular group, which I feel is a destructive cult, they literally keep their innermost, doctrine secret. In fact they people that they will die if you hear this information before you're ready. Time magazine did a cover story in 1991 -- Scientology: the Cult of Greed -  they were sued and they went through an entire legal process, and the court found that Time magazine said everything correct about Scientology..."
Russ Baker: Almost every journalist that has ever covered Scientology has been harassed. 
Frank Ofman from Scientology: We're here to help people. That's really what our purpose is. We are a religion, we are here to help people improve their IQ, their intelligence, help them live better lives.

episodes.title: Greater Boston: Bob Minton Interview 3
episodes.description:
Dennis Erlich was locked in the basement by the Church of Scientology for 10 days. He left the church and became a critic. He put sensitive internal materials from the church on the Internet, and Scientology officials marched right into his house to delete and remove whatever they pleased. Russ Baker talks about the case on the phone.
